Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
A competition experiment between wintering Redstarts and resident Yellow Warblers in Jamaican mangrove forest

In the Caribbean, the winter influx of billions of migratory songbirds coincides with low arthropod abundances, and food shortages can limit wintering songbird populations. Despite recent progress in understanding migratory bird ecology, the question remains: how do so many ecologically similar migrant and resident species coexist during the most resource-poor time of year? All available evidence suggests that food-based competition allows coexistence of migrant and resident birds in Jamaican mangrove forests, yet no published study in any system has experimentally demonstrated that interspecific competition for food exists between migrant and resident birds. The primary objective of this study is to perform a reciprocal removal experiment to determine whether interspecific competition exists between resident Yellow Warblers (Dendroica petechia) and wintering American Redstarts (Setophaga ruticilla). This study will quantify and compare: 1) resource use (three-dimensional territory size, foraging behavior), 2) fitness indices (body mass change, spring departure date), and 3) density of Yellow Warblers and ecologically similar American Redstarts on control (unaltered) and experimental (one species removed) mangrove plots.

This project seeks to determine if food-based competition drives coexistence between resident and migrant birds, providing much needed insight into the processes that maintain migratory bird populations throughout the annual cycle. The study will maximize interactions with Jamaican and Caribbean/Hispanic students by recruiting field technicians from underrepresented groups and hiring at least one Jamaican field assistant each year. In collaboration with the University of the West Indies, two five-day field courses will be run for undergraduate- and graduate-level Jamaicans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Every autumn, billions of migratory songbirds depart North America for the Neotropics, where they spend 6–8 months wintering alongside ecologically similar year-round residents. In the Caribbean, the winter influx of migrants coincides with low arthropod abundances, and food shortages can limit wintering songbird populations. Despite recent progress in understanding migratory bird ecology, the question remains: how do so many ecologically similar migrant and resident species coexist during the most resource-poor time of year? Interspecific competition has long thought to drive the structure of migrant-resident bird communities, but evidence is still equivocal and it remains an unresolved, yet central issue in migratory bird ecology. All the available evidence suggests that interspecific competition for food and space allows coexistence of migrant and resident birds in Jamaican mangrove forests, yet no published study in any system has experimentally demonstrated that interspecific competition exists between wintering migrant and resident birds. Insectivorous birds inhabiting Jamaican mangrove forest during the Boreal winter provide an ideal opportunity to investigate ecological interactions and consequences of coexistence of wintering migrant and tropical resident species. 

The primary goal of this study was to determine whether interspecific competition exists between resident Yellow Warblers (Dendroica petechia) and wintering American Redstarts (Setophaga ruticilla), a critical step toward understanding the importance of resource-based competition as a mechanism influencing avian population processes. 

First, we looked at redstarts returning to winter in our plots between years. Twenty redstarts with at least some overlap with mapped Yellow Warbler territories returned to the same mangrove plots between 2014 and 2015.  14 of the 20 birds decreased their 2D overlap with Yellow Warbler territories between years, which was highly significant overall (mean = -28.3%). 

Second, we used 2D territory mapping techniques to quantify the 2D overlap of redstart and Yellow Warbler territories, and to see how this varied by age of the redstart. Younger (less experienced) redstarts had about twice as much overlap with Yellow Warblers as their older counterparts, further suggesting that given experience, redstarts will choose territories that avoid the dominant species. 

Third, we performed removal experiments by 3D mapping territories of 35 redstarts with and without Yellow Warblers. Male redstarts—especially second-year birds—moved into Yellow Warbler core areas when Yellow Warblers were absent. Second-year female redstarts moved away from Yellow Warbler core areas during removals—probably because dominant second-year males were defending the newly available, resource-rich space against other redstarts.

Finally, we looked at indices of fitness for redstarts to see how this correlated with 2D overlap with Yellow Warbler territories. Old male redstarts shoed a particularly strong negative trend, whereby birds that were in poor condition were those with territories most overlapping those of Yellow Warblers, and vice versa. 

Together, these findings provide evidence on several fronts that migrant and resident birds compete for space (territories) and that there are consequences of this competition the manifest in the form of individual fitness (e.g., body condition). 

 

Broader Impacts

In an effort to broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in science, I hired three Jamaican field technicians.  One was hired for a job with the Jamaican National Environment & Planning Agency (NEPA), a second went on to several other ornithological field positions associated with the Smithsonian and the third I hired twice more for fieldwork help.

I further broadened participation by underrepresented groups by collaborating with Dr. Leo Douglas (University of the West Indies, Kingston, Jamaica & Columbia University) and others on a project entitled: "The effectiveness of a bird-science experience on the knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors of Jamaican students towards birds" (see photos).  The objectives of this project were twofold: 1) to increase Jamaican children's' awareness of and participation in science, wildlife, and environment, especially with respect to birds; and 2) to determine if single day field trips (nature walk, visit to a banding station, holding and releasing a wild bird) positively affect middle school students' (age 12-14) attitudes towards biodiversity conservation etc.  Although many schools and NGOs undertake these types of nature field trips, remarkably little is known about the short- or long-term effect of such experiences.  To determine these effects, we surveyed ~350 students on their attitudes towards nature/conservation/birds five times: 1)prior to a day-long field experience, 2)immediately after the classroom-only part of the experience, 3) after the field trip part of the experience, 4) after one year. In addition, each school received a series of bird/wildlife related books, two booklets, three posters, and Jamaican bird identification cards.
